Awesome food and service! The servers know exactly how to read their customers' body language. They always check around and look to see if anyone is need of a drink refill etc. They're also very quick and accommodating.  Food-wise, EXCELLENT. I've had both ramen and rice dishes as well as the dumpling and takoyaki appetizers. Everything is made in-house which is a huge plus and rare nowadays. The only reason why I couldn't give it 5 stars is because I wish the portions were a little bit bigger considering a bowl of ramen ranges from $10-15 per bowl.  Would definitely go here again!

Being born and raised in Japan, I tend to be harsher when it comes to Japanese food (and I try not to give 1 or 2 star reviews unless I visited the place a couple times). The service was good/normal, but I honestly don't know how Kenzo stays in business. The noodles are unremarkable (I can probably go to an Asian supermarket and get a better one), and the soup did not have a lot of flavour.   I never thought I would say this ever in my life, but I think I can make a better ramen. It was equivalent to a ramen I would get at an AYCE sushi restaurant, and it hurts to know that ramen is their main food at Kenzo.  I may try it again in a couple years because I don't like leaving 1, 2 star reviews.

I'm pretty sure that this is the only ramen place in Mississauga that I know of (excluding those in the food court), but nevertheless, the ramen here is fantastic. This place has friendly service and is always busy. I always leave feeling full and satisfied and a bonus is that there is chattime right next door for bubble tea. They also have vegetarian options, which is a plus point. I only had a bad experience once, which was when I tried their newest option on their menu: Tsukemen. The issue I had with this was that the noodles were clumped together and therefore made it impossible to eat. I had to ask for a fork and knife and ended up cutting up my noodles, which made me look like an idiot. Therefore, unless they have changed their recipe for Tsukemen, order anything else on the menu and you won't be disappointed.

Expect line ups outside the door during weekends and dinner times. Ramen consists of bouncy noodles that sit in a rich broth and accompanied by several slices of pork and vegetables. Tried both the shio and shoyu ramen and both were equally delicious and highly recommend them.

This Kenzo Ramen seems to be solo eater's heaven!  Not only it has tons of tables for 2 which are perfect for single, there were in fact 5 tables of single while I was eating there.   Wait staffs are a lot friendlier than the other locations I been to, especially the Dundas location.  My Netsu Ramen ($8.95) level 3 spicy also a lot spicier than the one I had in other locations?! The noodles were chewy and cooked al dente.....really warmed me up on this cold winter's night!  Another great Ramen location if I have a Ramen Attack!!

After being to all 3 locations of Kenzo Ramen in Toronto, This particular Kenzo now officially won "The Worse Services" and "The Most Unfriendly Waitstaff" award.   Though I cannot fault the food... the Ramens we ordered were excellent... But in order to eat that Ramen we have to endure crappy and unfriendly services?!!   No smile, No greetings... Just point...at the empty table  You ask for something, no acknowledgement.. if you lucky you might get what you request?  No Thanks, No Bye...   For me is BYE... since now your location is NOT the only one in town!!

Service here is bad. Food here is mediocre.   One hot summer day, I came here during a slow period, only one or two tables were taken. I was seated at a table directly under the air conditioner. I was freezing so I asked to move to a booth or another table. They told me no because I only had a party of two and booths and the other tables were for a party of 4 or more. After telling them I'm freezing, they turned the air conditioner off, just to turn it on 2 minutes later.  Regarding the food, it was okay. Nothing special. You can find better ramen down the street at Sansotei.

Kenzo Ramen, in the neighbourhood, has been a diet mainstay for a couple of years now.  I have probably eaten here 10 or more times, and it's a go-to on a rainy day.    It can get pretty busy and the tables are in close quarters--basically ambience-free, Kenzo is pretty much just about the noodles.  And they're good!  I usually get the Tonkotsu or King of Kings, both of which fill the ramen void within.   The broth is really good, the slices of pork are tender and moist, and you'll leave stuffed.  The service is often sporadic and rushed, but I'm paying $7 for dinner and the food always comes out fast.  It's a great fix if you're in the neighbourhood; if you're specifically seeking out excellent ramen or want great service, there are definitely better places to do that.
Po's king of the king ramen is really tasty and full of indigents. mine is you u ramen which is okay. Maybe a little bit salty in the end
Nice ramen place in Missisauga. I love the spicy ramen broth with bamboo and pork. Try the rice too

Got the King(?) Ramen. Asked for it to be medium hot which they accommodated and was divine. It was delicious and so filling! I was very happy with my order. We also got the takoyaki to share. I dont think I habe ever had a better takoyaki! And I have been to actual japanese restaurants known for this dish. It was crispy on the outside and warm and goey on the inside.   The service? Slow... But only because there was only one person working that day. This place still gets 5 stars because the server was amazing! He did his best with the crazy workload he had and did it with a smile. And honestly that makes a difference in dining experience.   Yes I will come again. Yes I will order the same things.

As ramen places go this was all around solid.  There was a wait for a table but leas than 15 mins.  Menu was pretty standard but pricing seemed high for a bowl of noodles.  7.95-12.95...our table had tokoyaki to start which were great but again pricey at 9.95.  Also tried the tuna fish onigiri which was quite tasty.  Some if the ramen brother was spicy and from the non spicy section so that was a bit if a downer.. Then we were promised a 20% discount and was never given it.  Want to give thus one another shot, but it will all depend in if we can find something better before the ramen itch

Flavors from the pork belly are great.  Noodles are exactly what you are looking for when you are craving ramen.  Octopus balls had good flavour but seemed a little under done. Pricing overall is average to a little higher than you would find in mist downtown noodle houses but decor is very clean and staff is uber friendly and helpful.

LOVE IT!!! There may be a wait list during the busy days/nights but it's worth the wait. The servers at burhamthorpe rd was super nice and gave us more ice on water on a very hot day!  HOWEVER!!! I have to lose 1 star for a reason (applicable to all Kenzo stores): their chopsticks are made out of metal and if you know science, if you eat a hot noodle using something metallic, metal will be hot as hell. The amount of times I burnt my mouth and my lips with this thing while having a nice hot ramen is unbelievable. It's not safe at all, I rather use a shitty plastic chopsticks than eat a burning metal one.

The Toronto location's much better, but because it seems to be the only legit ramen house in Mississauga as of yet (hopefully more in the future), I'll give it that extra star for convenience and accessibility.  I always enjoy their takoyaki, Ji Su Men, and their friendly greeting whenever I walk in and out of the door.

According to the Toronto Star, "Kenzo's tonkotsu ramen is awash in sodium. Its 3,388 milligrams is about 1,000 milligrams more than the maximum recommended daily allotment".  While I am not a fan of licking-salt, I would make exception for joy molecules-inducing food.   Unfortunately, the food at Kenzo was a disappointment. The Orochong Ramen ($8.95) was not flavorful. The supposedly Hokkaido favorite topped with stir fried green onions, green peppers, red peppers, mushrooms, chicken and cabbage was over powered by salt.   Takoyaki (around $9.00) filled with octopus, green onion, cheese and shrimp flavouring was doughy. It lacks the crispy exterior one comes to expect from Takoyaki.   Chicken Karaage (around $7.00) traditional Japanese fried chicken was one of the worst dishes we had that day. What is supposedly juicy on the inside and crispy on the outside was spongy on both counts. How Kenzo managed to create such an abomination is beyond my comprehension.    There is an endless loop of 90s heart-wrenching music playing the background in Kenzo. One speculation was that the chef was crying in the back kitchen. The sodium from his/her tears was incorporated in the soup and perhaps also contributed to the soggy Karaage.

I come here once awhile for Ramen. Great atmosphere and service.  Food are fresh and nicely presented.  However the potion might be small for my stomach and taste is too salty side for me..  otherwise it's a great lunch out place.

I got the Netsu ramen in medium and boy was it spicy! Next time I'm getting mild. It was still decent although I'm not a fan of the noodles. Decent portion size. I tried the Tonkotsu Ramen as well and I preferred that. The broth and meat were delicious in that one. It seemed a bit small especially for the price.

The Agedashi tofu that we ordered for a starter was good, but the soy sauce based ramen was lackluster. Next time we will try a different type of ramen. If you like green tea like we do, definitely try the smoothie! But ask for half the sweetness, it's more than enough.

Not the greatest but certainly good enough for me to get a quick ramen fix.   My only complain is their exorbitant charge for adding more tonkatsu. The waiter wasn't sure of the extra charge and told me it would be between 1 to 2 bucks. I said either way is fine. Well, I only got TWO extra slices of pork and was charged $2.50!!! I felt totally ripped off but hopefully this will not repeat with another customer.   The green tea latte was great. The authenticity of the tea can be tasted from the the matcha powder they used.   Overall decent place except for my misadventure of the tonkatsu.

Came here with a friend for a quick lunch . I got the miso ramen and my friend got a yakisoba.  We loved our food. I do feel the miso  was a bit on the salty side . The pork was tender and the noodles were soft.  My friends yakisoba  was flavourful but slightly oily . Overall a good experience. If we are in the mood for a quick meal sure why not  . A big plus point was the presence of an outlet to charge our phones.  We foodies need to charge our phones  to take pictures  of our meals and update social media with them.

My favourite ramen place in Mississauga! The atmosphere is super friendly, they have great appetizers on top of their ramen, and their ramen is the best I've had in the area! Not to mention they're super vegetarian friendly (but make sure to mention that you don't eat fish as well!)

If you're looking for a simple and good tasting noodle soup dish, this is the place to go. The kitchen operates well and seems to be able to fulfill orders quite quickly. Prices for the ramen dishes are also fair, if not very affordable. I would recommend going with their recommended menu options as they truly are delicious!

WHAT TO TRY?!  Of course their ramen! But you get to choose - spicy, tonkatsu based, soy based among many different soup bases they have. I personally like tonkatsu based soups because of its creaminess but it can be heavy, so shoyu soup base may be a good option too. Seafood ramen is good with LOTS of seafood!   I ordered the king shoyo ramen which was double the size of the regular shoyo. You get double the ingredients and toppings, and noodle too! It did have the soy sauces tangy flavor which was good!   My friend ordered the netsu ramen which had a kick of spice in the soup. Instead of pork, the chicken option was ordered. Pieces of chopped chicken was added to the bowl instead.   The bowls were pretty big and can be an inexpensive meal if you want something quick. Lots of other options to order and you can also order donburi which are the rice dishes if you're not feeling ramen.   They don't allow you to choose thickness of the noodle though.   LAST TIP?!  It's always sooo busy at this restaurant since it's the only ramen specialty restaurant in Mississauga. So come either right when it opens or when they're closing or else be prepared to wait! It's first come first serve basis, however on weekends, they can call your number to let you know you're next so you can walk around the plaza close by before they call you!

I've been living in Sauga for the majority of my life and I've probably been to Kenzo like 4x rofl. I've been told that it's not the greatest compared to ramen joints in Toronto and they're not wrong. Kenzo is always so busy.. especially during prime dinner time. I came on a Tuesday evening around 445pm and there was no rush of people yet. By the time we left, there was a line up of people! So if they're busy on a Tuesday night, chances are they're busy every night lol. I think Kenzo is the only ramen place in Sauga.. so maybe that's why it's really busy (?).   The first 3x I went, I didn't like the ramen. Then I'm hearing that it's gotten better recently. Turns out I was craving ramen today and since it's the only one in Sauga.. I'll give it another go. We got seated quickly and made our order. It took forever for our food to come out and I was surprised cause the last time I came it was really busy but I got it fast. I ordered the King of King noodles because I like ramen soup bases that has some spice to it. There's 3 levels of spice and I got the 2nd one. I liked the level of spice the soup had. Was perfect.  The King ramen actually had a lot of veggies in it and I don't like that at all. Felt like there was more veggies than noodles and the bowl looked massive. There were mushrooms, seaweed, green onions, carrots, bamboo shoots, cabbage, and bean sprouts in it.  Bean sprouts, green onions and bamboo shoots were good in it but everything else felt out of place. Way too much crunching in ramen   Ramen noodles were mediocre.  The pork pieces was soft and tender and the sliced egg was pretty good too.  Service was decent.   Sadly, all the times I've come here to eat were a bust.. don't think I'd be coming back.

After all my visits to this restaurant. It's still one of my favorites restaurants in mississauga and one of my favorite places to get gyudon.   Their Gyudon (beef on rice) is extremely delicious. I usually get my order without ginger and 2 additional raw eggs. Would totally recommend it. I love how it's really flavorful and juicy. The rice and beef blend perfectly together.   The service here is excellent. Every time i come here, it feels like home. All the services are extremely friendly and attentive.    There's always a wait here during rush hours like lunch and dinner. So to avoid the wait, come during off hours.

There are not a lot of good choices around the Eaton Centre for lunch or dinner, but this is my standby.  The dishes have a bit of a Korean spin to them, but the broth is well done (sometimes a tad salty), the noodles are good, and I haven't had a bad experience with service as others have.

I have to echo the sentiments of my fellow yelpers in saying that this place was mediocre at best, and the (lack of) service was what tipped it from being a three star experience to a one and a half or two star at most.   Our server was terse and forgetful - if this is, as some have said, "par for the course" when eating at a Japanese or Korean restaurant I'd honestly rather just cut the cuisine out of my repertoire entirely. I don't have much room in my dining life for terrible service. Within seconds of sitting down we were urged to order appetizers, yet we hadn't even been provided with menus. When I saw a nearby table snacking on steamed edamame, I decided to order it, only to be told that they don't have edamame on the menu. English was very limited so I didn't have the energy to argue.   I ordered the "orochong ramen", and thankfully one of my dinner mates spoke Korean and was able to request a vegetarianized version. I honestly feel like whenever I eat at an Asian restaurant I am at the mercy of the chefs when it comes to respecting my dietary preferences. I can never be sure if what I'm eating is truly vegetarian. It's a real trust thing.   The food was piping hot and the portion was ample. It was a little spicy for my tastes (and I like spicy food) and I was only able to finish about 1/5th of my meal. Despite this, the server didn't once ask if anything was wrong with my food or if I wanted to take it to go. It just sat in front of me, untouched, until after I had left. Apparently one of my dinner mates DID ask to have her food wrapped up and never saw it again. I wouldn't return.  Cash only.
I really enjoy the food here it is tasty and fresh. Hard to get seats as it is  popular but for a good reason.  You might want to call ahead to see how busy it is.

There is not many seats so even though the line may be short, it may take some time to be seated. Tried to come here for weekday lunch a few times, but there is always a line.  So I finally waited the line out and had some of their nice miso ramen!! Nice shop. Definitely a nice place to get your noodle soup fix.

I'm pretty sure they just opened the dundas location recently, and the place they had at Yonge/Finch was just too far from me despite hearing very good things.  So I was pretty excited to try it, and it didn't dissapoint.    They do have a limited menu right now but I'm sure that will change in time.  I don't think they had tonkotsu so I settled with some salt-based ramen which was ok, but I definitely want to head back to try some other flavors.    The staff was obviously new, but polite and it was pretty fast.  All in all, just excited about a decent ramen place in the core of the city.  Hopefully this will spawn several new ramen noodle joints and become the new Pho.

To temporarily satisfy a ramen craving, this will have to do. We got the tonkotsu and miso ramen, both of which was OK.  I kept waiting for that punch of flavor to hit me, but so many spoonfuls later, it just never hit the spots. The broth was fatty, just slightly bland.  While I'm a newbie to the Toronto ramen scene, I've been to my fair share of ramen spots in LA and some in New York, and this place barely scratches the surface. Left me wanting more. So the search for good ramen in Toronto continues.

I had the Tonkatsu ramen here during the dinner time and I thought it was alright. It wasn't very filling, but it was generally decent. The noodles were good and the soup flavor was great, but I wish the portions were slightly bigger.

The food was excellent as well as the service, especially on a cold night. Got a ramen Bowl, gyoza and onigiri and all were delicious. My girlfriend got the yakisoba and she said it was quite tasty (it certainly looked good). Would definitely come back here
Food's good. Service is fast. Try the Netsu Ramen. I've tried level 2's got a good kick to it, but doesnt burn your tongue.

Ramania. Noun. Desperately seeking out ramen the moment the temperature drops below 20 degrees celcius. In a sentence: I have ramania.   Had my first Kenzo ramen of the season the other night, and it was fabulous. I love their Tonkotsu pork ramen, add hot sauce. Beyond this dish, I prefer a couple of other ramen joints, but this one they do very, very well.

This place is busy and for good reason. The soup base has tremendous flavour. And so many to choose from! There's a lineup everytime I go but the wait makes the meal all the more desirable. I think a bit of wait is always a good way to build up hype and anticipation. Great way for kenzo to get noticed by passers-by.   Great spot for dates, family dinners and friends. If you like some spice and kick when you indulge in ramen, this is the place for you!

I actually came here in the summer with friends but never got to try it because of the long wait times. So today I got a chance to try it out.   We both ordered the tonkatsu ramen for lunch. It came out fairly quicky and tasted pretty decent imo. The slices of pork were my favourite! So tender and soft. The broth was a bit salty and the presentation wasn't that nice to post on instagram.  Overall, it was okay but nothing special. I'm not a ramen person so I think one time is good enough for me.

Kenzo is the only ramen restaurant that I am aware of the existence of a Nagasaki-style champon ramen on its menu. And it didn't disappoint me at all!! The seafood and the tonkatsu soup was a perfect combination! And the bowl is so giant and the volume of the ramen is way more than what I expected. I can't even eat it up.

Love it. They are so friendly. The food is fresh and taste great. You can ask them for vegetarian broth which they will gladly do. The takoyaki are great they taste really good it's very authentic. The onigiri is really good as well.
Pork pan fried Dumplings are perfect!! Black garlic ramen was sooooo good!! Service was good!!
This place is alright - portions are bigger than Santosei but quality is lower than that of Kinton. In a pinch, it should do to quelch any ramen cravings.

I have tried Kenzo ramen long before Sansotei or Santouka opened in the same area, honestly when I first tried the ramen at kenzo, I liked it. Though I am not sure if i have tried other Japanese owned ramen nearby and I found a comparison between both, and i do think sansotei ramen is better than kenzo, the tonkotsu ramen from kenzo is good, the milky taste which is very tasty, but the noodle itself i would like sansotei or santouka more. I would still come back again for lunch though.
Always come here for RAMEN LEVEL 3 SPICY, the taste is the best if compare to other RAMEN on queen st. The service is incredible great and fast.  Totally Recommend.

Not really worth coming out of your way to this place. Okay if you're looking for a ramen fix. Place is run mostly by Koreans from what I can tell. Seems like a lot of people come here but food is very medicore.

I was not a Kenzo fan because of its below average quality ramen. But yesterday my gf took home a fried noodle take out for me, the chicken and veggies were burnt(visually) and tasted bitter, the person who made the noodle could have remaked one but instead, he let the customer bring this burnt food home. Will never order any takeouts from this store.
